title: Julie - Ann Russell returns as Gleeson names Ireland squad for England and France
body_text:
LAST UPDATE | 3 Jul 2024
EILEEN GLEESON HAS named a 26-player squad for the Republic of Irelandâ€™s upcoming Euro 2025 qualifiers against England and France.
The headline inclusions are returning duo Julie-Ann Russell and Marissa Sheva, while Kyra Carusa is among those ruled out through injury. Denise Oâ€™Sullivan, meanwhile, will captain the team against England in Katie McCabeâ€™s one-game absence.
Ireland will play the Lionesses at Carrow Road on 12 July before hosting France at PÃ¡irc UÃ­ Chaoimh on 16 July in their final two Group A3 games.
The squad for our upcoming games against England and France ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡ª#COYGIG | #OUTBELIEVE pic.twitter.com/hJHFlJ3pd7
â€” Ireland Football âš½ï¸ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡ª (@IrelandFootball) July 3, 2024
Russell last featured for the WNT in March 2020. The 60-cap international is back in the squad after some excellent form for Galway United in the SSE Airtricity Womenâ€™s Premier Division â€” and giving birth to her one-year-old daughter, Rosie, last summer.
â€œSheâ€™s super fit, we know that sheâ€™s a phenomenal worker without the ball, her work-rate is excellent, she brings experience,â€ Gleeson said as she named her squad this morning.
â€œAnd then on the ball, she likes to dribble. We feel she can really add to the squad with experience and with the type of player that she is.â€
Carusa (hamstring), Heather Payne (achilles), Chloe Mustaki (hip), Tara Oâ€™Hanlon (hamstring) and Jamie Finn (knee) are out through injury, while defender Niamh Fahey returns to the squad alongside Oâ€™Sullivan and Sheva. Lucy Quinn, meanwhile, misses out, while Cork City captain Eva Mangan retains her place.
Portland Thorns attacker Sheva has been absent since last summerâ€™s World Cup, but â€œhas been waiting on the call and been proactive in trying to get back inâ€. She ultimately gets the nod in Carusaâ€™s absence.
â€œKyra is a huge loss to us,â€ Gleeson said, â€œobviously sheâ€™s a big presence around the camp and within the team. Sheâ€™s a consistent starter, so a huge loss. She pulled up in a warm-up at the weekend and has since been scanned. It is a torn hamstring, so longer-term.â€
McCabe will miss the England game as she serves a suspension, so Oâ€™Sullivan will captain the team on her own return from a knee setback.
â€œWe all know Katieâ€™s a huge player but we still have to move forward and itâ€™s the same with Kyra, we have to use the whole squad. We have to adapt to that. Itâ€™s time for other people to step up. Denise will step into the captainâ€™s role.
â€œItâ€™s brilliant to have her back. Obviously we know Deniseâ€™s qualities. She is a very steady presence, she is a great leader and we know her work-rate on the pitch is second to none. Itâ€™s key to have her. Unfortunately we donâ€™t have Katie at the same time, but having Denise is really, really important.â€
Asked if her thinking has changed in terms of tactics as a result, the manager said: â€œWe know Katie is a key player, weâ€™ve used the back three and the back four and not having Katie of course impacts that.
â€œSheâ€™s very versatile, she sat well in the left-full position. Itâ€™s not a position where weâ€™re overloaded in richness in the full-backs areas. Weâ€™re often having to adapt players into that role, and change their role so of course it changes the thinking but again itâ€™s back to always being adaptable and using the squad that you do have available then.â€
A point over the next two games would be â€œhugeâ€ as Ireland prepare for the play-offs after struggling in the Group of Death.
â€œWe all know weâ€™re in a direct race with Poland for the final seeded place. It will be down to goal difference and of course, points first of all.â€ (Theyâ€™re both on zero points but Ireland currently have a better goal difference.)
What about the lack of goals scored? â€œOf course itâ€™s a huge challenge,â€ Gleeson responded, not fully answering the question.
â€œWe want to get to a position where we can be higher up the pitch, competing and staying up in presses,â€ she added separately.
The squad will assemble in Dublin on Sunday, after a four-day preparation camp last week â€” which included a Taylor Swift concert â€” given the tricky timing of this international window.
â€œItâ€™s a big challenge,â€ Gleeson concluded. â€œEvery team is having it. Itâ€™s not a window thatâ€™s typically in the calendar, itâ€™s because of the Olympics. It brings its challenges.
â€œWe have a lot of players playing in the Championship, they finished at the end of April and weâ€™ve obviously got players in the WSL, that finished at the end of May. Itâ€™s quite a big off period for the Championship players, and a big challenge to have them ready for the spike in intensity and load against teams like England and France.â€
Ireland WNT Squad
Goalkeepers: Courtney Brosnan (Everton), Grace Moloney (London City Lionesses), Sophie Whitehouse (Lewes)
Defenders: Jessie Stapleton (West Ham United), Diane Caldwell (FC Zurich), Louise Quinn (Birmingham City), Niamh Fahey (Liverpool), Caitlin Hayes (Celtic), Aoife Mannion (Manchester United), Anna Patten (Aston Villa), Megan Campbell (London City Lionesses)
Midfielders: Katie McCabe (Arsenal), Denise Oâ€™Sullivan (North Carolina Courage), Megan Connolly (Bristol City), Lily Agg (Birmingham City), Ruesha Littlejohn (London City Lionesses), Tyler Toland (Blackburn Rovers), Jess Ziu (West Ham United), Izzy Atkinson (Crystal Palace), Eva Mangan (Cork City), Julie-Ann Russell (Galway United)
Forwards: Amber Barrett (Standard Liege), Leanne Kiernan (Liverpool), Abbie Larkin (Crystal Palace), Emily Murphy (Wake Forest University), Marissa Sheva (Portland Thorns)
